----- Original Message -----
From: "Robert Watkins" <robertdw@...>
To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Friday, October 25, 2002 6:53 PM
Subject: Re: [junit] Junit test


> On Sat, 2002-10-26 at 05:56, Jonathan Gossage wrote:
> > I have used this technique quite successfully but there is one naging
> > problem that I have not solved. Typically with data driven testing you
> > have one test method (or possibly a small set of methods) and each
> > method runs many tests. The Junit TestCase class uses the method name
> > as the test name and I would really like to have a unique name for
> > each test (which is easy to provide in the test data.) Has anyone any
> > ideas on how to address this issue?
>
> Yes.
>
> Oh, you want to know what they are? :)
>
> You need to change the name of the test to match that provided in the
> test data. There are three ways to do this:
> 1) Pass the name in via the constructor. This works well, because you
> are passing in lots of other stuff (the test data).
> 2) Use the setName() method of JUnit 3.8
> 3) Override the getName() method (just name() in earlier versions).
>
> However, all of these techniques have a common problem: they cause the
> default implementation of TestCase.run() to break. This is because
> TestCase.run() uses the name to look up the test method via reflection.
> So, if you've changed the name, you need to change the TestCase.run()
> method as well.

Been there - tried that ;-)

That was exactly the problem I encountered when I tried manipulating the
name. The problem is that these test cases need to run on a variety of IDEs
each with their own implementation of TestRunner. I have found that the
Eclipse implementation will tolerate name changes but JBuilder does not seem
to.
>
> A quick read of the code for TestCase, and (to a lesser degree)
> TestSuite, will help you out here.
>
> Robert.
>
